claim: Cell- and egg-based flu vaccines have the potential to develop mutations during production, which may reduce their effectiveness.

extracted_evidence.quote: In traditional quadrivalent standard dose inactivated influenza vaccines (SD-IIV4), chicken eggs are used to manufacture the vaccine strain.
extracted_evidence.relevance_explanation: This quote establishes that standard dose flu vaccines are produced using chicken eggs, which is relevant because the process of growing viruses in eggs is known to potentially introduce mutations, supporting the claim about mutation risk during production.

extracted_evidence.quote: The recombinant formulation is not susceptible to antigenic drift during manufacturing.
extracted_evidence.relevance_explanation: This statement directly contrasts recombinant vaccines with egg-based vaccines, implying that egg-based vaccines are susceptible to antigenic drift (mutations) during manufacturing, which can reduce effectiveness.
